reviewText: If you're reading this, you have probably already tried at least one of the other Tomb Raider games, and are wondering, How will I react to Tomb Raider 5: Chronicles compared to the other Tomb Raider game(s) I have played?". I will try to review Chronicles based on its quality relative to the other classic games in the series (i.e. the ones developed by Core).\n\nCompared to the first four classic games
date: Chronicles is fairly short and (for me) probably the easiest out of the five "Core classics". I enjoyed the varied settings in the game's 13 levels
recommended: and I think the developers did a great job in creating a suspenseful atmosphere despite a dated graphics engine relative to that time period of PC gaming. To support this atmosphere
hoursPlayed: there are plenty of varied puzzles (although they are nowhere near as difficult as Tomb Raider 3's puzzles)
voteText: good use of ambient sound effects to set the mood
votesTotal: a fun avoidance/stealth-based mechanic where the clunky combat is non-existent.\n\nChronicles is split into four locations and unfortunately I feel that only the first location (Rome) has that traditional tomb-raiding feel which I so dearly love. I don’t mind the occasional “modern-day” level; however I felt that Chronicles was a bit too heavy on modern-day exploration (more than half of the levels are in modern-day settings). This is a matter of taste
votesFunny: but one of the things I really appreciated about some of the older Tomb Raider games was getting immersed in the lore of Ancient or lost civilizations. So
commentsCount: while the atmosphere of Chronicles is overall still suspenseful and well-crafted
column16: I felt that the game lacked that “epic feeling” that certain levels of previous Tomb Raider games provided (I’m looking at you
column17: Temple Ruins of Tomb Raider 3 and St. Francis’ Folly of Tomb Raider 1).\n\nTLDR: Chronicles is a decent “classic” Tomb Raider game
column18: despite it being relatively short and easy
column19: and lacking a certain epic atmosphere that all 4 previous games possessed. I would only recommend it if you have played some of the other classics (i.e. 1-4) and are just looking to add to your collection for a very cheap cost ($6.99 for approximately 10 hours of gameplay). If you’re completely new to the series and are looking to start your Tomb Raider experience

reviewText:
Lara Croft seems to be gone forever and the bereaved tell four stories about the action-packed life of hers. Will the fifth part of the franchise meet the expectations?Hint: At the end of this review you will find a TL;DR section.

----------------------------------------------------------------

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
It is the year 2000, five years have passed since the first Tomb Raider game was developed by Core Design and published through Eidos Interactive. Five years of changes in its development, gameplaywise and graphicwise, marks one of the most known franchises. But something just did not went the way it should have, so it seems.

Months after Lara's adventure in egypt she still has gone missing and is now presumed dead. After a memorial in her honor, the bereaved sit together and relate about some of her biggest adventures. Four small stories await the player: the hunt for the Philosopher's Stone in Rome, the Spear of Destiny in Russia, a short trip to the haunting places in Ireland and a thievery in a high-tech office complex to gain the Iris artefact again, that Lara has found back in Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation.

Compared to Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation nothing much has changed. The graphics and also the engine are carried over from the previous game. Still, Lara got even in this small follow-up new movements, which refresh the gameplay a little bit. She is now able to balance on tightropes, swing around on a horizontal bar and perform a somersault out of tight spaces.

The stories are self-contained, which means that everything the player collects in the sublevels will not get carried over into the next story. This counts for weapons incl. the ammunition, as well as for medikits, what makes hoarding them pretty much useless. Yet, with the different armories the player has now the opportunity to play with the Desert Eagle and the Revolver in one game.

Level design and also the puzzles" are mostly very confusing and seem not well-conceived. This ends not unusually in frustration
date: since the player gets stuck more often in a level than in the previous games - with the need to get a hand on a guide.\nThe difficulty rises up harshly and since there is no way to change the difficulty at all
recommended: the players are either forced to clench their teeths and play through the hardest parts with/without a guide or to give up near the end.\n\nTomb Raider V: Chronicles could have been a great space filler between TR IV and TR The Angel of Darkness. Sadly
hoursPlayed:
it could not even reach the greatness from the past classic Tomb Raider games.

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
The high expectations I had on Tomb Raider V: Chronicles while following the journey through the very first level were cut down rapidly. On its release I skipped it for several reasons without knowing what could stand behind the fifth game of this big franchise. The whole game itself felt more like an add-on for Tomb Raider IV than an actual follow-up
voteText: created in a hurry. The idea behind the stories was great and interesting yet poorly executed and after a while very boring. Tomb Raider V: Chronicles is compared to the other classic games only a weak tail light and does not show the actual intensity of the earlier games.\nAlso the difficulty made me rage more than one time
helpfulPercent: since many solutions were not clear and did not make much sense. In the very last story - I have to admit - my patience and passion just passed away and I did not mind going any further. The fact
votesHelpful: that I had to use guides did not satisfy me and in the end I had to uninstall the game unfinished.\n\nSadly
votesFunny:
not even for fans of this franchise.

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ TL;DR]▬▬▬▬●

[✔] Interesting idea of self-contained stories
[✔] Each story has its own armory
[✔] New acrobatic moves
[✔] Contains a level editor

[✖] Confusing level design and puzzles
commentsCount:
plus hardly possible to play some parts without a guide
[✖] Items don't carry over into the next story
[✖] Game feels more like an add-on than an actual follow-up
[✖] Clunky keyboard-only controls
[✖] Graphics still primitve compared to todays standards
[✖] Fixed camera

reviewText: In this game you play 4 different Lara's adventures: her search for the Philosopher's Stone in Rome, her hunt for the Spear of Destiny (imo, this is the best level of Chronicles), her adventure on the Black Isle (only puzzles on this one, 'cause you play with a younger Lara who doesn't use guns yet) and the final level is her infiltration on Werney Von Croy's high-tech complex to retrieve the Iris Artefact (the one you see at the beginning of The Last Revelation).\nEven though TR: Chronicles isn't as good as its predecessors, it still is a great game. Chronicles uses the same engine from The Last Revelation, which improved Lara's movements, making it much easier to play, but the graphics are still the same (not a bad thing, it's really good for a PS1-era game). The variety of the scenarios got my attention here: you go from the Coloseum to the deep of the ocean to the island of Lost, among others. I highly recommend this if you're a fan of the series, but if you're just starting to play the old TR games, check out TR 2 and The Last Revelation first (I know some people don't like TLR, but it was my first TR game so it has a special place in my heart). The only really bad thing is the save bug on the last minutes of the game, so make sure you don't save only on one slot and search on the internet where the bug starts to cause problems and you'll be good to go.

reviewText:
TR5 is the last oldschool Tomb Raider game. It features the same visuals as Tomb Raider 4 and also includes some new moves.
Chronicles tells us four stories about Lara's previous adventures (the events before The Last Revelation). The Rome is set before Tomb Raider 1 (1996), Russia is somewhere in the middle, Ireland when Lara was 16 (same age as in TR4's Cambodia levels), New York (when she decided to steal Cambodia's Iris from Von Croy).
The game is somewhat notably shorter than the previous parts, but it features some variety. Rome was similar to TR2's Venice style adventures. Russian submarine was similar to TR3's modern vibe. Ireland is quite a unique experience, you could even tag it as survival horror. VCI headquarters is more similar to The Angel of Darkness concept of modern Tomb Raiding.
Unlike TR4 the TR5 is completely linear, you can't go back between the levels and on top of that each time you finish a chapter (on of four) all your items are gone. On the bright side that prevents item hoarding. The game has 36 secrets. Collecting all unlocks game's concept art.

TR5 has native widescreen support. There's no need to patch it.

In a perfect world this should be played after finishing:
- Tomb Raider (I)
- Tomb Raider: Unfinished Business
- Tomb Raider II
- Tomb Raider II: The Golden Mask
- Tomb Raider III: Adventures of Lara Croft
- Tomb Raider III: The Lost Artifact
- Tomb Raider IV: The Last Revelation
- Tomb Raider IV: Exclusive Times Level

reviewText:
Tomb Raider V: Chronicles is definitely the worst in the Classics series. Not only is the level design uninspired, very basic and just plain boring at times, the four little episodic stories are absolutely horrendous. This game feels more like something a single hobby developer put together in a week than an actually official Tomb Raider title.

It does have its moments and some levels and designs aren't quite as bad and lackluster as others but overall it's a very dull, short and often times downright annoying and buggy experience that you can skip if you're not a completionist or fan of the series.

On a scale of 1 to 10 I would give Chronicles a 3 for trying to implement at least a few unique ideas and new gameplay mechanics that haven't been seen before in a Tomb Raider game.

reviewText:
Chronicles gets a lot of hate, and rightfully so. It's easy to see how, at the time, a fifth Tomb Raider game in five years, which added few changes could be seen as downright insulting - almost as antiquated as any of the tombs within.

Replaying it now, over 15 years later, it's easy to look back with rose-tinted glasses and talk about how it follows the classic formula. Unfortunately, it follows that formula too closely, in fact, it's the most generic Tomb Raider in the franchise, and frankly, the only one I didn't look forward to replaying.

4/10.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This may be the shortest of the Tomb Raider games.  It's set after Tomb Raider IV, when Lara's supposed to have died (I won't ruin the surprise, but there's a Tomb Raider VI after this one ;-)   It's chopped up into small stories, which break up the game into nice little episodes set at different times and in different locations.   The original Tomb Raiders can really drag sometimes, but this one has good pacing, an interesting story, and there's just enough variety to keep you interested.   It does have a few bugs, though, which can be a pain, but they're easily avoided if you keep a walkthrough handy.   As with all the original series TR's, level design and low poly models are really starting to show their age now, which is a shame, but it's a good member of the series, and a great trip down memory lane. Well Recommended for holiday fun.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider Chronicles is a great memorial to the legendary Lara Croft after the events of the last game. We learnt she wanted some of Harry Potter's Philosophers Stone, a trip on a Russian sub, flashbacking to grim Ireland to talk to the demons with a priest who treats exorcism like a tea party and she spites old Von Croy in a wheelchair in the good ol' US and A in his own company HQ! We globetrot with our favorite female icon through stories told by old friends sitting around a fireplace after the memorial, getting steadily drunker.

It's a gentle and perhaps thankfully easier pick up and play title after the titanic epic of The Last Revelation and a breather from the relentless TR3, perfect for novices or those who want to breeze through the game without too much difficultly. That said, although the difficulty isn't too high, it boasts the hardest (and buggiest) final level to date; the perhaps ironically named Red Alert.

Highlights for me are the Italian levels with their lovely visuals and beautiful scenery injected with some good humor from series stalwards Larson and Pierre from TR1, now a bumbling comic duo that set to try and thwart our heroine but fail horribly! The Russian levels are very tense, particularly in the Deepsea Dive and Sinking Submarine levels. Ireland does well with the grim, macabre setting to instil a creepy atmosphere (Labyrinth gets props for being eerie) and as Lara is unarmed, it adds to the drama! The final stages are very hi-tech, a huge contrast to the rest of the game act as a thrilling hi-octane conclusion!

I recommend you play this after you play the first four so you get a good feel for the Core Design era before Angel of Darkness plunged it into....uh darkness. Such a shame they rushed AoD, it would have been interesting to see what future installments that could have been. But to fully live the Core Design era, start at the beginning and have yourself a TR marathon.

TRC has a special place in my heart even to this day!

reviewText: All of us knows that the Tomb Raider is a legendary video game. Especially, It's the first of its kind. reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend this Tomb Raider game since it's linear in comparison to the previous Tomb Raider games.

Though if you are into this game for the story of Lara's past life before the events of The Last Revelation and none of the first three Tomb Raider series then this game would at least show you some of her experience in various episodes. It uses the previous Inventory system as The Last Revelation so not exactly the best one.

Pros        Cons                Episodic: Unique strategy of gameplay each episode.        Small bugs still appear in the game and sometimes prevents to proceed further after saves.                Sounds: Still work fine and music plays out without much glitches        Not really a con: Controls remain the same like the previous four games.                Settings can be adjusted before playing: 1920x1080        FMV's still shrink the screen to 640x480
I'd recommend for players new to the Tomb Raider series but also prefers games that is quite short then this is the game for them. For those who likes long games and lots of puzzles to solve around then I wouldn't recommend this game. It's at least a 6.5 / 10 for me.

reviewText: I understand why many people didn't really appreciate this game but I enjoyed it. It's not structured like a single complete game, instead it's more of a collection of smaller almost expansion set worthy adventures. While these adventures were short, I thought they were at least interesting and most importantly fun. The Ireland levels were particularly memorable because they were spookier than any others in the TR franchise. Each story is quick and fun, and each reveals a bit more about Lara's past and character. So I welcome this game as a worthy addition to the franchise, even if its structure isn't ideal.\n\nUnfortunately, like TR2 & 4, this game is forced into a window in Windows 8...so I won't recommend it... otherwise I would.

reviewText:
Probably the worst in the series. It was after Last Revelation but the graphics were even worse. But that's not the worst part. The worst part is:

THE SAVE STATE BUGS

These developers seem to need a crash course in state transition development. I won't go into details, but if you play this game you must continually save in staggered save slots because when you save a game and then load it again, it doesn't always load in the same state you saved it in. Neccesary enemies may not spawn, switches may not be activated any more, water may not be drained...the last level is the worst for this.

Just DO NOT overwrite saves unless they are old. Cycle through every time you save so you can always go back to before a trigger problem occurs.

You have been warned.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider: Chronicles started off so promising, so well set up. The opening cutscene had me hooked. Is Lara really dead? Who knows? Winston finally gets a role other than cannon/freezer fodder, opting to recount Lara's past expeditions around the globe to Father Patrick Dunstan, after a memorial service for her is held. Meanwhile, Werner von Croy, Lara's mentor and rival, continues excavating the Temple of Horus in hopes of finding her after the events of The Last Revelation.

But after the opening cutscene, I've made a stunning revelation myself: this game is utterly soulless, lazy and devoid of heart. In my reviews of Tomb Raider II and III, I made comments addressing that I found them to be more effective as expansion packs rather than sequels, but still good games. Chronicles, however, feels more like a map pack created by someone who had the Tomb Raider concept hastily explained to them in 2 minutes.

There's only 13 levels this time around. To boot, a lot of them are incredibly short. The amount of puzzles has been reduced, an addition that I really loved from the Last Revelation, instead opting to return to key, switch, door and backtracking from Tomb Raiders I-III. The levels are also annoyingly easy, except for the final level, which is ridiculously hard and total change of pace from the previous 12. Here's a breakdown of the levels:

1-4: Reskinned Venice levels from Tomb Raider II with a hint of the Greece levels from Tomb Raider I.
5-7: Painfully unoriginal snowy Russian base and submarine levels. Cause that's never been done before.
8-10: Okayish levels pretty much stolen from Shadow Man/Medievil. Seriously.
11-13: Why is Lara Croft stuck in the Matrix now? Why didn't you take the blue pill?!

Lara's new techniques include: tightrope walking and swinging from horizontal bars. As usual, these additions are barely noticeable as they appear about 3 times each throughout the entire game. Because the level system jumps around to different time periods, Lara's inventory is reset at the beginning of each set, which is actually a pretty good addition. Secrets have been replaced by golden roses which, upon collecting them all, unlocks an artwork menu (yay). If you miss one, you miss out, but it really doesn't matter. It's not worth it. There's also no vehicle sections either, other than a crappy underwater mission which is irritatingly short (literally 2 minutes).

Not to mention that it's filled with some irritating bugs as well. Using hotkeys for medkits depletes your supply, but doesn't actually heal you half the time. Weapon hotkeys don't work anymore. A couple of times Lara just refused to draw her weapons, whether I used the draw key or equipped it from the inventory menu. Saving also screws up for a lot of people, but thankfully I never encountered this issue. The final level is ghastly in its bugginess.

Plotwise, well, what plot? It's four completely random episodes thrown together. This entire game is totally unnecessary in the overarching plot from Tomb Raider through to The Angel of Darkness. The concept is good, but it's executed so poorly that it's just sad. The only connection that Chronicles has to past entries is, at the end of the game, Werner von Croy finds Lara's backpack. It would be a spoiler, but come on, we know she's still alive, and playing through this dreck really isn't worth such an equally pitiful ending.

The sound is just average. I don't know what happened to Peter Connelly's great soundtrack from The Last Revelation. Most of the music is gutted, reused or remixed from previous entries. Egyptian-themed music from The Last Revelation is used, for example, in the depths of water beneath a Russian submarine. It doesn't flow and it's just freaking lazy. Voice acting is just bad all around. Stereotypical Americans, Frenchmen, and Russians flood the cutscenes, of which there are inexplicably many, consistently interrupting the little gameplay that there is. Voice volume is also far too low, leading to important dialogue, such as hints given by Zip in the final 3 levels, being missed.

Oh, and the camera! My God, the camera. The fixed angles are revolting, obscuring your view and disabling the use of the look function. Meaning that, unlike in previous entries, if you wanted to return to your normal view, you just pressed look or draw weapon. Here, nope! Enjoy this beautiful tilt while you fall to your death, or this stunning pan while you get the ♥♥♥♥ shot out of you by  a helicopter!

The game somehow looks worse than The Last Revelation. Lara's model remains unchanged from the previous year, and only a small amount of levels actually take place inside a tomb, the rest of which are cities, military bases or submarines. I'm all for variety, but it is called TOMB Raider. Why the sudden aversion to one of the core (no pun intended) elements of the game? Human models other than Lara look downright awful, especially Father Patrick's. Time Crisis on PS1 had better models than this game. The only above-standard thing about this game is the pre-rendered cutscenes, and even they aren't up to scratch with other games released in the same period.

I suppose one other good point about the game is its disappointing length, which means that it's over quickly, even though it feels like an eternity. I passed Tomb Raider: Chronicles in five hours. FIVE HOURS. It's one of the most disappointing games I've ever played. And if you're afraid of missing out on some plot details, don't be. This game is worthless in every aspect.

2/5.

reviewText: About fifteen years after finishing the 4th opus, I decided to continue. The first thing I noticed is the appearent lack of graphical improvement. However this is not critical as it is an old game. However, the background story is absolutely horrible, illogical and barely understandable. The last level was so difficult that I ran out of medics and could not complete it. A large part of the game relies on the player's ability to master the long jump to the cm, and after breaking Lara's legs for the hundredth time I had enough of it. I found the puzzles sometimes interesting, but many puzzles do not rely enough on logics but rather on try and fail" until you exhaust every possible interaction with the game environment.\nWhat would you say about a game that you abandon at the last level with the bitter sensation to have wasted time?"

reviewText: This game ruined my childhood. My PC was so old and i couldn't play anything but some crappy indie games of early 2000's and this. Controls were horrible, graphics weren't so good to see important details of level; so that was extremely hard to reach next levels. Jump was ridiculous as well, you have to think milimetric before jumps, because that could be ended with Lara's death or trying crossing the same path all over again.\n\nI'll try to play this again... with a gamepad. On PlayStation, first five games' controls were better. But probably that won't change my hatred to Tomb Raider: Chronicles.

reviewText:
To be honest, it's not the best part of the series, but it really is good for beginners. It's not that difficult as other parts (like TR3 and 2) and you can really casually play it, furthermore because it's not too long.

If you're a fan of the classic series and haven't played it yet, than you should buy it. It's a good game.

And I'd say thanks to Steam I don't need to patch it and it works perfectly fine on my Windows 7.1 PC.
